name: Tower Defense Starter
description: Assets for a classic tower defense game with buildable towers, enemy waves, paths, and resource management UI

packs.reason: Medieval battle units for enemies (soldiers, cavalry), buildings for towers, and terrain tiles (16x16px)
Terrain tiles, path tiles, trees/rocks for obstacles, tower structures, and projectiles (16x16px)
Buttons for build menu, panels for tower info, and UI elements

tower_basic.notes: Basic tower (2x3 tiles); use tl/tr/ml/mr/bl/br for full tower

tower_archer.notes: Building tile from tiny-battle; combine with tile-091/108/109 for full structure

tower_cannon.notes: Castle tower for heavy defense (2x3 tiles); use tl/tr/ml/mr/bl/br

enemy_soldier.notes: Basic infantry unit from tiny-battle; variants: tile-037/038/039

enemy_cavalry.notes: Mounted unit for fast enemies; variants: tile-055/056/057

path_straight.notes: Dirt path tile; combine tl/tr/bl/br for path segments

path_corner.notes: Stone path for corners; combine tl/tr/bl/br tiles

path_start.notes: Open gate for enemy spawn point

path_end.notes: Castle base for player's base to defend

terrain_grass.notes: Buildable terrain; variants: grass-light-2/3/4, grass-medium-*, grass-dark-*

terrain_water.notes: Water obstacle (unbuildable); combine tl/tr/bl/br for pools

obstacle_rock.notes: Rock obstacle (blocks building); variant: rock-grey-2, rock-brown-1/2

obstacle_tree.notes: Tree obstacle (2x2 tiles); use tl/tr/bl/br for full tree

projectile_magic.notes: Magic projectile (use gem sprites); variants: gem-red, gem-green

ui_button_build.notes: Build button for tower menu (64x64); variants: button-round-*, button-rectangle-*

ui_panel_info.notes: Info panel background (192x64); use for tower stats display

ui_coin_icon.notes: Gold coin for currency display; variant: coin-silver

ui_star.notes: Star rating for tower upgrades or wave completion

gameplayNotes: Towers use multi-tile sprites (2x2 or 2x3); combine tl/tr/bl/br/ml/mr tiles for full structures
Enemy units from tiny-battle are 16x16px single tiles; use tile number variants for visual variety
Path tiles from roguelike-rpg-pack use 2x2 groupings (tl/tr/bl/br) for proper corners and edges
Terrain tiles have numbered variants (1/2/3/4) for visual variety in grass and dirt
Water tiles are 2x2 (tl/tr/bl/br) and should block tower placement
Obstacles (rocks, trees) block both paths and building; trees are 2x2 tiles
Use gem sprites as magic projectiles when arrow-1 doesn't fit tower theme
UI pack buttons come in flat/gloss/gradient/border/line styles and multiple colors
Coin sprites work well for resource display; use coin-pile-* for treasure/rewards
